references.A69PLA01USGP: Platt, D.R. 1969. Natural history of the hog-nosed snakes Heterodon platyrhinos and Heterodon nasicus. University of Kansas publication Museum of Natural History 18(4): 253-420.

references.B96DEG01USGP: Degenhardt, W., Painter, C., and A. Price.  1996. Amphibians and reptiles of New Mexico. University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 429 pages.

habitat_description:
From NatureServe

Palustrine Habitat(s): Riparian
Terrestrial Habitat(s): Cropland/hedgerow, Desert, Grassland/herbaceous, Shrubland/chaparral, Woodland - Hardwood
Habitat Comments: Habitat consists of areas with sandy or gravelly soils, including prairies, sandhills, wide valleys, river floodplains, bajadas, mesquite grassland, thornscrub, semidesert areas, creosotebush desert, open montane woodland, semiagricultural areas (but not intensively cultivated land), margins of irrigation ditches, and sometimes mountain canyon bottoms (Degenhardt et al. 1996, Hammerson 1999, Werler and Dixon 2000, Stebbins 2003).


From SWReGAP 
Grasslands with sandy soils serve as typical habitat. In New Mexico, habitat is found in many places from creosotebush desert to open montane woodland where sandy or gravelly soils suitable for burrowing are available. Typical habitat includes sandhills, plains grassland, sandy floodplains, often, in the vicinity of, or along the margins, of the streams, irrigation ditches and ponds. Occurs in Cochise, Graham, Santa Cruz Counties in Arizona.
